finding: The SNP rs7836366 exhibited strong positive linkage disequilibrium with rs7005905 and rs10100209. This finding was pivotal in corroborating the association of the SOX7 gene with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), emphasizing the biological relevance of these variants.
title: SOX7: Novel Autistic Gene Identified by Analysis of Multi-Omics Data

finding: The SNP rs10100209 showed strong positive linkage disequilibrium with rs7005905 and rs7836366, contributing to the identification of SOX7 as a gene significantly associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The strong LD highlighted the genetic interactions important for ASD phenotypes.
title: SOX7: Novel Autistic Gene Identified by Analysis of Multi-Omics Data

finding: SNP rs7837688 was associated with substantial structural changes in the lncRNA, impacting RNA binding protein interactions.
title: Effect of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms on the structure of long noncoding RNAs and their interaction with RNA Binding Proteins

finding: The SNP rs80207740, a promoter SNP, achieved a PIP of 0.97 for red blood cell count using PolyFun + SuSiE, while it had a PIP of 0.28 with SuSiE alone, showcasing the advantage of incorporating functional annotations in fine-mapping.
title: Functionally-informed fine-mapping and polygenic localization of complex trait heritability

finding: SNP rs751141 was linked to variability in oxylipin levels, specifically 12,13-EpOME, and was associated with the missense mutation R221Q in the enzyme EPHX2, demonstrating its significance in RBC metabolomics.
title: Genome-wide metabolite quantitative trait loci analysis (mQTL) in red blood cells from volunteer blood donors

finding: The association of SNP rs28603189 with docosahexaenoic acid (FA22.6) replicated under stringent quality control criteria, demonstrating its relevance in association with RBC metabolites.
title: Genome-wide metabolite quantitative trait loci analysis (mQTL) in red blood cells from volunteer blood donors

finding: The SNP rs13266634 was associated with the SLC30A8 gene, which encoded zinc transporter 8 (ZnT8). This genetic variant has been established to have a strong association with the risk of developing type-2 diabetes (T2D), primarily due to its vital role in insulin secretion and glucose homeostasis.
title: Causal network perturbation analysis identifies known and novel type-2 diabetes driver genes

finding: The rs9331896-TT genotype of CLU was identified as a risk factor for Parkinson's disease (PD) in a previous study. The findings indicated that activated astrocytes in the spinal cord injury (SCI) model exhibited high expression levels of Clu during the acute and subacute stages, which subsequently decreased at the intermediate stage. This temporal expression pattern suggested a potential therapeutic avenue where CLU-loaded biodegradable materials could be utilized to manage glial scars by controlling the release rate of CLU.
title: Spatiotemporal dynamics of molecular expression pattern and intercellular interactions in glial scar responding to spinal cord injury

finding: An association was identified between rs34591516 (p.Gly313Ser) in GPR20 and diastolic blood pressure (p=1.8×10⁻⁶, β=0.028, 95% CI: 0.017-0.04), corroborating prior findings.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs75686122 was associated with cocaine dependence, and a novel haplotype block was identified, which included the SNP within the RIMS2 gene. Three novel internal exons that were highly conserved were detected, contributing to predicted additions of amino acids to the RIMS2 protein.
title: Targeted, High-resolution RNA Sequencing of Non-coding Genomic Regions Associated with Neuropsychiatric Functions

finding: The SNP rs41475248 was identified as having synergistic effects in the context of type II diabetes, as indicated by the analysis of concordance among various methods of detection utilizing Kendall's tau. This suggests that interactions involving rs41475248 play a significant role in the genetic basis of type II diabetes.
title: Novel Methods for Epistasis Detection in Genome-Wide Association Studies

finding: The SNP rs10111784 was identified as having limitations in MODIS-derived phenological metrics within Pan-Arctic landscapes, highlighting its importance in understanding the challenges in accurately assessing leaf phenology in different ecological regions.
title: A general model for the seasonal to decadal dynamics of leaf area

finding: The rs13263296 variant (C>T) was linked to early natural menopause (ANM) and located in the DEPTOR locus, a gene involved in mTOR signaling. It was found in the putative transcription start site-proximal enhancer of the DEPTOR gene in several ovarian cell types. While there was upregulation of DEPTOR expression in aged granulosa and epithelial cells, rs13263296 was not significantly associated with increased DEPTOR expression overall, possibly due to the bulk tissue used in the eQTL analysis. Predictions indicated that this variant might enhance transcription factor binding, thereby affecting DEPTOR expression.
title: The regulatory landscapes of human ovarian ageing

finding: SNP rs10956838 was jointly linked to decreased SA of the parietal operculum in ADHD, suggesting its genetic significance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs7014426 was part of a connection with lower SA in ADHD, indicating its impact on brain structure.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs13263075 linked to increased thickness in the perisylvian cortex for ANX, demonstrating its role in cortical structure.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs6997571 exhibited associations with increased surface area in the temporal pole for BD, indicating its influence.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs6984358 was jointly associated with reduced SA and CT in primary sensory cortical regions relevant to BD and SCZ, showcasing its shared role.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: The SNP rs892844 was associated with the potential CTCF binding occurrences identified in the study. Specifically, GRAFIMO retrieved three potential occurrences overlapping the dbSNP annotated variant at the genomic region chr8:142,782,661-142,782,680. This finding indicated that variations at this SNP could influence TF binding landscapes, which are crucial for understanding transcriptional regulation and its implications for disease states.
title: GRAFIMO: variant and haplotype aware motif scanning on pangenome graphs

finding: The SNP rs147998249, a missense variant Val452Leu in the GPT gene, strongly associated with ALT levels (p < 10^-300), marking it as a significant variant influencing liver enzyme levels.
title: Genome-wide association study of circulating liver enzymes reveals an expanded role for manganese transporter SLC30A10 in liver health

finding: It was associated with T-follicular helper cells and mapped to the SH2D4A gene, indicating a role in T-cell antigen-induced cytokine synthesis.
title: Germline genetic contribution to the immune landscape of cancer

finding: This SNP served as a caQTL for a CD4+ T cell-specific site, with significant allelic effects (π=0.65, q-value=0.013), indicating its influence in T cell functions.
title: Mapping genetic effects on cell type-specific chromatin accessibility and annotating complex trait variants using single nucleus ATAC-seq

finding: Located in the AGPAT5 gene, this SNP showed similar strengths of associations across triglycerides, LDL, HDL, and total cholesterol, evidencing its relevance in lipid phenotype associations.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: Located near the RPL35AP19 gene, this SNP showed the strongest association with obesity and weaker associations with type 2 diabetes and hypertension.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: The lead variant rs28531929, an intronic variant in COL22A1, reached genome-wide significance in association with RRD.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: This SNP was identified as the refined lead variant for an association signal with RRD, indicating a significant genetic contribution.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The SNP rs6983267 was associated with cancer risk, particularly showing long-range interaction with the MYC gene in colorectal cancer contexts. This finding highlighted the involvement of enhancer variants in the pathogenesis of cancer.
title: Rapid and Quantitative Functional Interrogation of Human Enhancer Variant Activity in Live Mice

finding: The SNP rs7010179 was identified as a significant genetic variant associated with the activity of cyclin-dependent kinases in human cancers. The original finding suggested that variations at this locus could influence the efficacy of targeted therapies aimed at cyclin-dependent kinases, supporting the relevance of CDK2 in cancer treatment strategies.
title: Mechanistic insights into the phosphoryl transfer reaction in cyclin-dependent kinase 2: a QM/MM study

finding: The SNP rs28560301 was associated with the AD-related locus NDUFAF6. It demonstrated decreased predicted binding affinity for the transcription factor PAX5 with the risk allele. Following IL-6 exposure, PAX5 expression increased, while risk allele activity of rs28560301 significantly decreased compared to baseline, indicating a dynamic interaction between the SNP and the environmental cue.
title: Dynamic stress- and inflammatory-based regulation of psychiatric risk loci in human neurons

finding: The SNP rs10100391 was associated with the modulation of choline metabolism through choline kinase alpha inhibition. This inhibition was linked to altered immune responses in macrophages and had implications on tumor growth reduction and metastatic dissemination in breast cancer models, as evidenced by the study published by Mariotto et al. (2018). The research demonstrated that choline kinases play a critical role in immune modulation and could affect choline metabolism during infection or cancer processes.
title: Choline metabolism underpins macrophage IL-4 polarization and RELMα up-regulation in helminth infection

finding: The analysis of SNP rs6993770 revealed a strong association with platelet granularity (PLT-SSC) and various plasma proteins. It was shown to increase granularity and alter structural properties in neutrophils while being linked to increased plasma levels of proteinase-3 (PR3). The risk allele was associated with changes in multiple platelet-derived proteins, suggesting a pleiotropic effect influencing both platelet formation and plasma concentrations.
title: Genetic Analyses of Blood Cell Structure for Biological and Pharmacological Inference

finding: The rs10866912 variant in MROH-6 was predicted to have opposing effects based on the type of substitution; substituting T with C decreased expression, while substituting with G increased expression. This variant was identified as part of a binding site for the transcription factor INSM1.
title: Predicting cell population-specific gene expression from genomic sequence

finding: The study identified rs10110411 as a significant marker for predicting colorectal cancer prognosis, highlighting that its association was particularly notable in women with right-sided colon cancer (RCC). This marker was correlated with gene expression differences that impacted metabolic processes and immune responses, which ultimately contributed to the observed disparities in clinical outcomes between right and left-sided cancers. This finding was particularly relevant because it suggested the potential for using rs10110411 as a prognostic biomarker specifically for female patients diagnosed with RCC.
title: Molecular pathway analysis indicates a distinct metabolic and immune phenotype in women with right-sided colon cancer

finding: The SNP rs1160267 was identified as the most significant GWAS SNP mapping within a downstream enhancer of NKX3-1. It correlated with NKX3-1 enhancer H3K27ac activity (ρ = 0.35; p = 1 × 10^-3), indicating its role in chromatin modification. Conversely, it showed no significant correlation with NKX3-1 expression levels. This finding underscored the potential for rs1160267 to affect chromatin states in a manner unattainable by standard eQTL methodologies, thereby implicating it in prostate cancer risk through its regulatory function rather than direct effects on gene expression.
title: Genetic determinants of chromatin reveal prostate cancer risk mediated by context-dependent gene regulation

finding: The SNP rs2553658 had a reported alteration in the TCF4 transcription factor motif, indicating regulatory implications, although direct functional evidence regarding the variant's association with PACG was less emphasized than for rs2553628.
title: Post-GWAS functional analyses of CNTNAP5 suggests its role in glaucomatous neurodegeneration

finding: The rs548251181 SNP, characterized as a GA to G indel, was relevant in the context of human glioblastoma (GBM) cells and was found to not align with the human hg38 reference sequence. Its presence was validated through MAPit-FENGC genotyping. This SNP demonstrated significant variations in single-molecule methylation heatmaps during epigenetic profiling, indicating its potential role in genetic and epigenetic modifications.
title: Flap-enabled next-generation capture (FENGC): precision targeted single-molecule profiling of epigenetic heterogeneity, chromatin dynamics, and genetic variation

finding: This SNP was associated with liver volume with a p-value of 2.1e-34 and a beta of -0.15. The association relates to liver health as it lies near the PPP1R3B gene, known for promoting hepatic glycogen biosynthesis, though it was not linked to liver fat or iron.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI

finding: This SNP was classified as a primary signal at the ANK1 locus with a TOA score of 0.97 for islet tissue, noting its association with a strong enhancer.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs4737010 was highlighted as fine-mapped for lymphocyte count and linked through the PPI-enhancer × ABC annotation. This SNP served as a notable marker for further understanding the genetic basis of autoimmune disease through its association with the implicated gene IKBKB, which is crucial for immune function.
title: SNP-to-gene linking strategies reveal contributions of enhancer-related and candidate master-regulator genes to autoimmune disease

finding: This SNP was associated with macrophage migration inhibitory factor levels and linked to NAPRT expression, illustrating its influence on inflammatory marker control.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: Similar to rs10093709, it was linked to immune regulation through its association with nicotinate phosphoribosyltransferase, enhancing understanding of metabolic regulation in inflammation.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: Detected in the C8orf4 gene locus, SNP rs13270586 displayed significant GxS interaction (p=1.55×10−7) and showcased opposite effects in males and females regarding risk for SCZ and BIP.
title: Sex-Dependent Shared and Non-Shared Genetic Architecture Across Mood and Psychotic Disorders

finding: This SNP was reported to be under positive selection in Sub-Saharan Africa and was identified as causal for zinc deficiency, impacting immune function.
title: Ohana: detecting selection in multiple populations by modelling ancestral admixture components

finding: The SNP rs10111787 was associated with significant influences of sea surface temperature on the range limits and expansion of mangroves in Eastern South America, particularly indicating how environmental variables like temperature patterns affected genetic variation in the black mangrove species studied, namely <italic>Avicennia schaueriana</italic>.
title: Geographic and environmental contributions to genomic divergence in mangrove forests

finding: The SNP rs3802177 was associated with significant colocalization with T2D GWAS signals, suggesting allele-specific expression impacting T2D risk.
title: TIGER: The gene expression regulatory variation landscape of human pancreatic islets

finding: The SNP rs11558471 exhibited significant cASE colocalization with T2D-associated loci despite lacking other forms of traditional eQTL evidence.
title: TIGER: The gene expression regulatory variation landscape of human pancreatic islets

finding: The SNP rs13266634 was highlighted for its strong linkage disequilibrium with another T2D associated variant, while also suggesting protective allelic imbalance.
title: TIGER: The gene expression regulatory variation landscape of human pancreatic islets

finding: Although not directly genotyped, rs1532277 in the CLU locus was validated as a causal variant via MPRA (p = 1.5 × 10−6) and CRISPR experiments in neurons (p = 6.4 × 10−5). Its linked neighbor rs1532278 was identified by CIT-Lasso as a potential causal variant.
title: Beyond guilty by association at scale: searching for causal variants on the basis of genome-wide summary statistics

finding: Linked to rs1532277, the variant rs1532278 was identified due to its proximity and association with causal effects at the CLU locus, emphasizing its relevance despite not being directly genotyped.
title: Beyond guilty by association at scale: searching for causal variants on the basis of genome-wide summary statistics

finding: Identified with a significant association in VAT volume studies (p=1.6e-10, beta=-0.04), supporting the link to body fat metrics.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The rs28834970 variant located within an intronic enhancer of the PTK2B gene was associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD). This SNP was found to create a novel binding site for the transcription factor CEBPB, leading to increased chromatin accessibility in macrophages and microglia. The introduction of the C allele resulted in global transcriptional changes, including a modest decrease in PTK2B expression in these cells, and an upregulation of CLU expression specifically in macrophages. Importantly, it was noted that the C allele led to a significant downregulation of several chemokine genes and reduced chemotaxis to C5a, suggesting that this variant could modulate microglial reactivity, potentially influencing AD pathogenesis.
title: An Alzheimer’s disease-associated common regulatory variant in a PTK2B intron alters microglial function

finding: The SNP rs10481349 was identified as a cell-type specific expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for oligodendrocytes. The study demonstrated a significant relationship between the proportion of oligodendrocytes, predicted by the DSA estimates, and the expression levels of the gene STMN4. Different genotype groups (0, 1, 2) for this SNP were shown to correlate with varying levels of STMN4 expression, highlighting the SNP's role in influencing gene expression within specific brain cell types.
title: Deconvolving the contributions of cell-type heterogeneity on cortical gene expression

finding: The rs73551705 variant at the BMP1 locus was significant in smooth muscle cells and associated with CAD risk variants.
title: Cell-specific chromatin landscape of human coronary artery resolves regulatory mechanisms of disease risk

finding: The minor allele of SNP rs1453213 at OXR1 positively correlated with Prevotella abundance (β = 2.23; P = 1.3 × 10−7) and negatively correlated with Bacteroides abundance (β = -0.049; P = 3.4 × 10−4). This finding was also part of the investigation into genetic associations with gut microbiome taxa.
title: M-GWAS for the gut microbiome in Chinese adults illuminates on complex diseases

finding: The missense variant rs73263258, which caused the p.Ala159Thr change, was identified in the ESRP1 gene located near the TP53INP/NDUFAF6 region associated with AD. This detection of a variant within a previously identified AD region underscored the likelihood of recessive variants contributing to the genetic architecture of AD.
title: Autosomal Recessive Alzheimer’s disease (arAD): homozygosity mapping of genomic regions containing arAD loci

finding: The SNP rs7830986, identified in the LACTB2 gene, was noted as the most significantly associated TWAS SNP specifically in induced monocytes. This synonymous variant is believed to regulate LACTB2 expression, possibly through its role within the lncRNA LACTB2-AS1 and an enhancer region, implicating it in immune response mechanisms relevant to Alzheimer's disease.
title: Monocyte-specific changes in gene expression implicate LACTB2 and PLIN2 in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The rs570512700 variant in the TERF1 gene was characterized as a SAS-specific splice site variant, with a relatively high occurrence of 74 in gnomAD exomes. Although it affected a highly expressed canonical isoform, it did not influence the isoform with the highest mean expression (average pext = 0.41). Exclusion of this prevalent variant resulted in a substantial increase in the estimated s<sub>het</sub> value from 0.0029 to 0.0412, indicating that the presence of such low-confidence variants can obscure accurate evolutionary constraint estimations.
title: Harnessing population-specific protein truncating variants to improve the annotation of loss-of-function alleles

finding: The SNP rs10808812 was associated with orofacial clefts (OFCs) as part of a suggestive GWAS locus. It was highlighted due to its significant p-value of 2.00 × 10−6, supporting its potential role in the etiology of OFCs. This finding was further contextualized by the identification of the gene ZFHX4, which also exhibited multiple loss-of-function de novo mutations, indicating a strong genetic implication in OFC risk.
title: Coding de novo mutations identified by WGS reveal novel orofacial cleft genes

finding: The locus associated with rs35006907 on chromosome 8 was linked to various cardiac structure and function phenotypes. It was strongly annotated as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for the MTSS1 gene, which supports a role in cardiac function and morphology.
title: Genomic analysis reveals a functional role for myocardial trabeculae in adults

finding: This SNP (282C>T) was identified as part of the NAT2 gene analysis where it contributed to the slow metabolizer genotype. The finding indicated that approximately 74% of participants were carriers of slow metabolizer genotypes which may affect drug sensitivity and risk of liver injury.
title: Allelic and Genotypic Frequencies of NAT2, CYP2E1 and AADAC genes in a cohort of Peruvian Tuberculosis Patients

finding: The SNP (341T>C) associated with the NAT2 gene was analyzed and contributed to the identification of slow metabolizer phenotypes present in around 74% of participants, thereby highlighting a potential risk factor for increased sensitivity to Isoniazid.
title: Allelic and Genotypic Frequencies of NAT2, CYP2E1 and AADAC genes in a cohort of Peruvian Tuberculosis Patients

finding: This SNP (481C>T) was part of the NAT2 analysis that identified a significant prevalence of slow metabolizers (74%) within the Peruvian cohort, increasing susceptibility to drug-induced liver injury when treated with Isoniazid.
title: Allelic and Genotypic Frequencies of NAT2, CYP2E1 and AADAC genes in a cohort of Peruvian Tuberculosis Patients

finding: This SNP (590G>A) was noted in the context of the NAT2 gene and found to be associated with the slow metabolizer phenotype, which was prevalent in approximately 74% of the study participants, thus demonstrating its relevance in drug response.
title: Allelic and Genotypic Frequencies of NAT2, CYP2E1 and AADAC genes in a cohort of Peruvian Tuberculosis Patients

finding: The SNP (803A>G) was included in the assessment of NAT2 genotypes and contributed to the characterization of slow metabolizers identified among 74% of the Peruvian population, linking it to increased risks of adverse drug reactions.
title: Allelic and Genotypic Frequencies of NAT2, CYP2E1 and AADAC genes in a cohort of Peruvian Tuberculosis Patients

finding: This SNP (857G>A) was part of the NAT2 gene evaluation that indicated a high prevalence of slow metabolizers (74%) in the cohort, which has implications for the metabolism of antituberculosis drugs.
title: Allelic and Genotypic Frequencies of NAT2, CYP2E1 and AADAC genes in a cohort of Peruvian Tuberculosis Patients

finding: The variant rs1532278 was found to modulate CLU expression in astrocytes, which further aligns with its association with AD risk, endorsing previous findings from related research.
title: Deconvolution of polygenic risk score in single cells unravels cellular and molecular heterogeneity of complex human diseases

finding: Located in a 5' UTR CRE of the LPL gene, rs1800590 was associated with CAD risk, demonstrating significant alterations in enhancer activity and suggesting its role in regulating lipid-handling macrophages.
title: Partitioning heritability using single-cell multi-omics identifies a novel macrophage subpopulation conveying genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: Found in an intronic CRE at the LPL locus, rs59811201 showed an association with CAD, confirming the relevance of LPL expression alterations in the context of atherosclerosis.
title: Partitioning heritability using single-cell multi-omics identifies a novel macrophage subpopulation conveying genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: This SNP resided in a distal intergenic CRE at the LPL locus and was part of a group of variants associated with CAD, suggesting coordinated regulatory impacts on lipid metabolism in macrophages.
title: Partitioning heritability using single-cell multi-omics identifies a novel macrophage subpopulation conveying genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: The protective G allele of rs11204086 was found to disrupt a NR1H3-binding motif, positively correlating with higher LPL expression, and indicated its crucial role in CAD risk modulation.
title: Partitioning heritability using single-cell multi-omics identifies a novel macrophage subpopulation conveying genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: Another variant localized in the distal intergenic CRE at the LPL locus, rs11204087 was linked with CAD risks, indicating the importance of genetic factors in atherogenic processes.
title: Partitioning heritability using single-cell multi-omics identifies a novel macrophage subpopulation conveying genetic risks of coronary artery disease

finding: The SNP rs6983267 was identified in the context of a study where mice lacking a Myc enhancer that included this SNP showed resistance to intestinal tumors. This finding indicated that rs6983267 had a significant role in tumorigenesis through its effects on the Myc oncogene.
title: Genomic context sensitivity of insulator function

finding: The SNP rs10110433 was associated with the findings related to high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC) as detailed in the study. It played a role in the regulation of the WNT7A-FZD5 signaling axis, which was critical for the self-renewal of Fallopian tube stem cells. These stem cells were identified as Wnt/β-catenin Active (WβA) cells, and this association with HGSOC highlights the potential significance of the SNP in the development and progression of this malignancy.
title: Single Cell Transcriptomics identifies a WNT7A-FZD5 Signaling Axis that maintains Fallopian Tube Stem Cells in Patient-derived Organoids

finding: The SNP rs10957177 was associated with the postcentral gyrus in a 100kb window on chromosome 8.
title: Genetic signatures of human brain structure: A comparison between GWAS and relatedness-based regression

finding: Linked to intelligence and schizophrenia, it was noted for its role in associative neuropsychiatric pathways.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: This SNP was identified as associated with systemic lupus erythematosus and was linked to the significant expression of the gene BLK, which is involved in B cell development. It was part of the nine variants that exhibited a strong signature of selection.
title: Ancient DNA reveals that few GWAS loci have been strongly selected during recent human history

finding: The SNP rs4871180 in chromosome 8 was associated with Diverticular disease in British individuals. The risk allele had a notably high frequency in the analyzed Native American populations, particularly compared to lower frequencies in Dominicans and Puerto Ricans.
title: Continental-scale genomic analysis suggests shared post-admixture adaptation in Americas

finding: The study identified the SNP rs1799998 (-344T/C) in the CYP11B2 gene as the primary focus for disease association studies. This particular mutation was noted for its potential diseased state association, particularly in relation to hypertension and cardiovascular diseases. It was part of a broader analysis where 29 deleterious SNPs were identified from a larger pool, emphasizing its relevance in the context of genetic predisposition to these health issues.
title: In-Silico Analysis of nsSNPs Associated with CYP11B2 Gene

finding: Associated with mood instability, rs1962104 predicted expression related to a splice junction and specific exons of the PTK2 gene, with significant findings in both LIBD and CMC datasets, indicating its role in mood-related physiological processes.
title: The genomic basis of mood instability: identification of 46 loci in 363,705 UK Biobank participants, genetic correlation with psychiatric disorders, and association with gene expression and function

finding: Within the scope of mood instability, rs2729940 was found to predict the expression of the largely unknown genes RP11-481A20.10 and RP11-481A20.11, showing greater abundance in brain tissues, thus implicating these genes in potential mood biology.
title: The genomic basis of mood instability: identification of 46 loci in 363,705 UK Biobank participants, genetic correlation with psychiatric disorders, and association with gene expression and function

finding: This SNP was linked to the expression of RP11-981G7.1, a gene uniquely expressed in the brain, marking it as significant in the context of mood instability and potential cognitive functions.
title: The genomic basis of mood instability: identification of 46 loci in 363,705 UK Biobank participants, genetic correlation with psychiatric disorders, and association with gene expression and function

finding: In relation to mood instability traits, rs4398922 was associated with the expression of three genes (FAM86B3P, FAM85B, and ALG1L13P), all exhibiting low yet consistent expression across various human tissues, pointing towards their possible involvement in mood regulation.
title: The genomic basis of mood instability: identification of 46 loci in 363,705 UK Biobank participants, genetic correlation with psychiatric disorders, and association with gene expression and function

finding: The SNP rs10097555 was solely associated with EHR-OSA in the African ancestry VUMC dataset with β = 0.20 (p = 2.30 x 10^-3) indicating its targeted influence in this population.
title: Characterization of Genetic and Phenotypic Heterogeneity of Obstructive Sleep Apnea Using Electronic Health Records

finding: The study identified rs41505344 as the most significant SNP associated with susceptibility to NAFLD, with a p-value of 1.64E-04 in a large cohort of 1,483 histologically characterized NAFLD patients compared to 17,781 matched population controls. Further quantitative trait analysis in the UK Biobank highlighted a significant correlation of rs41505344 with serum triglycerides and AST levels, suggesting that this genetic variant could modify protein function and contribute to NAFLD susceptibility.
title: Macrophage Scavenger Receptor 1 mediates lipid-induced inflammation in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease

finding: The SNP rs10090330 was linked to proliferative and invasive colorectal tumors in pet dogs, offering unique insights into human colorectal cancer, as detailed by Wang et al. in 2018.
title: Establishment and Characterization of Novel Canine Organoids with Organ-Specific Physiological Similarity

finding: The variant rs13266634 was confirmed as a significant T2D risk variant, showing biased expression toward the risk allele in human islet samples. It encoded an amino acid change (R325W) in the ZnT8 protein. It exhibited significant allelic expression imbalance, favoring the T2D risk allele (C) over the protective allele, as evidenced by cASE analysis.
title: Multiple genetic variants at the SLC30A8 locus affect a local super-enhancer cluster to influence pancreatic β-cell survival and function

finding: The rs11558471 variant demonstrated the most significant allelic expression imbalance in the context of <SLC30A8> expression, with a p-value < 4.64 x 10^-14, indicating it plays a role in the transcriptional regulation of the gene and, by extension, may influence T2D risk.
title: Multiple genetic variants at the SLC30A8 locus affect a local super-enhancer cluster to influence pancreatic β-cell survival and function

finding: The protective allele of rs3802177, though associated with lower transcriptional activity in promoter-luciferase assays compared to its risk counterpart, was found within a cluster of variants that may influence overall gene expression at the <SLC30A8> locus.
title: Multiple genetic variants at the SLC30A8 locus affect a local super-enhancer cluster to influence pancreatic β-cell survival and function

finding: The study found that mice lacking a Myc enhancer that includes the human SNP rs6983267 were resistant to the development of intestinal tumors. This finding indicated a significant association between this SNP and tumorigenesis, supporting the hypothesis that Myc regulation is pivotal in cancer biology.
title: Myc-dependent cell competition and proliferative response requires induction of the ribosome biogenesis regulator Peter Pan

finding: The SNP rs10090154 was located in the binding motif of the transcription factor FOXA1 on the MYC enhancer with a striking PrCa association p-value of 1.4e-188, indicating its major significance in prostate cancer.
title: The PENGUIN approach to reconstruct protein interactions at enhancer-promoter regions and its application to prostate cancer

finding: The SNP rs10110433 was associated with gene expression profiles related to ovarian/extra-uterine high-grade serous carcinomas (HGSCs). Specifically, it was found to correlate with heightened WNT signaling activity in cells derived from the distal region of the Fallopian tube epithelium (TE), which is characterized by increased organoid-forming capacity and stem/progenitor cell enrichment.
title: WNT and inflammatory signaling distinguish human Fallopian tube epithelial cell populations

finding: The SNP rs10503253 was reported as a genome-wide significant variant associated with schizophrenia risk. It was found to impact general cognitive ability and executive function in healthy males, suggesting that it has functional implications beyond schizophrenia, likely related to cognitive processes.
title: CUB and Sushi Multiple Domains 1 (CSMD1) opposes the complement cascade in neural tissues

finding: Located 800kb downstream of MYC, this emVar variant influenced T cell proliferation, indicating a regulatory role for MYC in T cell biology.
title: Linking candidate causal autoimmune variants to T cell networks using genetic and epigenetic screens in primary human T cells

finding: Similar to rs10098999, this variant impacted growth-related pathways in T cells by its association with MYC signaling.
title: Linking candidate causal autoimmune variants to T cell networks using genetic and epigenetic screens in primary human T cells

finding: This variant was implicated in regulating GRINA expression, expanding the understanding of T cell biology related to glutamate receptors.
title: Linking candidate causal autoimmune variants to T cell networks using genetic and epigenetic screens in primary human T cells

finding: Associations were found with rs2948300 on chromosome 8 related to essential hypertension. This indicates its potential role in cardiovascular phenotypes, linking it to broader health implications beyond obesity.
title: A Comprehensive Genome-wide and Phenome-wide Examination of BMI and Obesity in a Northern Nevadan Cohort

finding: The SNP rs4149252 was identified as part of the independent pQTLs for EPHX2. It suggested that increased EPHX2 protein levels were associated with increased levels of the target metabolite, highlighting a contrasting effect compared to rs2234887.
title: Probabilistic Fine-mapping of Putative Causal Genes

finding: The SNP rs751141, like rs4149252, was another independent pQTL identified for EPHX2 that suggested that increased protein levels would lead to an increase in the blood metabolite levels, presenting heterogeneity in gene-to-trait effects compared to rs2234887.
title: Probabilistic Fine-mapping of Putative Causal Genes

finding: The SNP rs2061831 was consistently prioritized in both European ancestry (EA) and African ancestry (AA) data due to its significant association with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and its ΔMGW value of 1.63 Å, which was 2 standard deviations above the mean. It was also linked to trans-ancestral SNP signals from SLE Immunochip analysis.
title: Intrinsic DNA topology as a prioritization metric in genomic fine-mapping studies

finding: The SNP rs4872174 was associated with prostate cancer. It was indicated that the risk allele C of this SNP decreased the expression of NKX3-1, a gene implicated in prostate cancer progression.
title: Large scale genome-wide association study in a Japanese population identified 45 novel susceptibility loci for 22 diseases

finding: The variant rs804271 in the GATA4/NEIL2 locus was found to be significant in a genetic association focused on regulatory elements. This variant was detected as being associated with PCOS and showed colocalization with gene expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs), emphasizing its relevance to the disease.
title: Gene regulatory activity associated with PCOS revealed DENND1A-dependent testosterone production

finding: The signal led by rs10111287 colocalized best with a VIRMA eQTL in thyroid tissue (PPH4 = 0.906), and also showed significant colocalization with VIRMA eQTLs in stomach and whole blood. This indicated that the signal was likely linked to regulating VIRMA gene expression.
title: Validation of human telomere length trans-ancestry meta-analysis association signals identifies POP5 and KBTBD6 as novel human telomere length regulation genes

finding: The SNP rs13262861 was identified within the ANK1 locus, linked to the nearby gene NKX6-3 in beta cells. Prior data from islet expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) studies had already indicated NKX6-3 as a target gene at this locus.
title: Single cell ATAC-seq in human pancreatic islets and deep learning upscaling of rare cells reveals cell-specific type 2 diabetes regulatory signatures

finding: The SNP rs2280104 was located within a PD risk locus on chromosome 8, which intersected with an eQTL for the gene CCAR2 in dopaminergic neurons. The findings indicated that this locus harbored significant PD risk associations as per the GWAS data, highlighting its potential influence on the molecular mechanisms underlying Parkinson's disease. Additionally, the eQTL data suggested that CCAR2 expression might be modulated by the genetic variation at this locus.
title: The Foundational data initiative for Parkinson’s disease (FOUNDIN-PD): enabling efficient translation from genetic maps to mechanism

finding: The SNP rs6983267 was originally found to be associated with a Myc enhancer, demonstrating that mice lacking this enhancer showed resistance to intestinal tumors. This finding indicated a critical role for this SNP in cancer susceptibility and progression.
title: Steroid receptor-assisted loading modulates transcriptional responses in prostate cancer cells

finding: This missense variant showed a strong association with decreased human GR activity, suggesting that it could potentially contribute to genetic variability in resilience to AD pathology. Its rarity in human populations also highlighted the complexity in identifying such variations in GWAS.
title: Hippocampus Glutathione S Reductase Potentially Confers Genetic Resilience to Cognitive Decline in the of AD-BXD Mouse Population

finding: An intron variant associated with decreased GR activity in humans that could influence resilience in AD, reflecting the need for further studies in genetically diverse populations.
title: Hippocampus Glutathione S Reductase Potentially Confers Genetic Resilience to Cognitive Decline in the of AD-BXD Mouse Population

finding: The G-allele of SNP rs6983267 was identified as a significant risk factor for colorectal and prostate cancers. It was found in approximately 50% of individuals with European ancestry and over 85% of individuals with African ancestry. This allele increased cancer risk by more than 20%, contributing to a substantial number of cancer deaths worldwide. Additionally, studies showed that deleting regulatory sequences syntenic to the super-enhancer region containing this SNP in mice resulted in healthy and fertile individuals, yet they exhibited high resistance to intestinal and mammary tumors. This highlighted a potential dual role of the genomic region in tumorigenesis and normal tissue regeneration processes.
title: Shared requirement for MYC upstream super-enhancer region in tissue regeneration and cancer

finding: Similar to rs39451, SNP rs39499 was also significant and located within the promoter region of KCS4. This SNP was implicated in the regulatory mechanisms affecting the lipid accumulation profile during carbon starvation.
title: Hello darkness, my old friend: 3-Ketoacyl-Coenzyme A Synthase4 is a branch point in the regulation of triacylglycerol synthesis in Arabidopsis by re-channeling fatty acids under carbon starvation

finding: The SNP rs6981405, an A-to-C transversion within the DDHD2 gene, was found to disrupt QKI binding and was associated with risk for schizophrenia. In the context of RBPNet analyses, it showed a significant reduction in predicted protein-RNA interaction signal amplitude for the alternative allele compared to the reference allele. This was quantified using Kullback–Leibler (KL) divergence to produce a KLD impact score, indicating that mutations within the QKI binding motif led to more substantial changes in predicted signal profiles than mutations outside the motif. Furthermore, feature attribution maps displayed a dramatic loss in positive prediction signals at the site of the mutation, reflecting its strong negative impact on binding.
title: Towards In-Silico CLIP-seq: Predicting Protein-RNA Interaction via Sequence-to-Signal Learning

finding: The em-Var rs922483 received the highest score among all LD-linked variants including GWAS SNP rs2736340, related to systemic lupus erythematosus, marking it as a significant finding.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: The em-Var rs56316188 scored highest compared to GWAS SNP rs2859998, linked to UBXN2B and narcolepsy with cataplexy, denoting it as a substantial finding.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: The SNP rs6981405 was identified as a significant variant in the DDHD2 gene's 3'UTR, which disrupts binding by the RNA-binding protein (RBP) QKI. This disruption was linked to an increased risk of schizophrenia. The finding was supported by genomic studies in different populations, demonstrating the strong association of this SNP with psychiatric disorders. Specifically, the research indicated that individuals with the homozygous AA genotype exhibited a loss of QKI binding to DDHD2, leading to alterations in mature DDHD2 mRNA abundance, which was relevant to schizophrenia risk.
title: Genome-wide landscape of RNA-binding protein dysregulation reveals a major impact on psychiatric disorder risk

finding: The rs34269950 SNP was linked to both obesity and metabolic syndrome, both of which are significant risk factors for developing heart failure.
title: Identification of biomarkers, pathways and potential therapeutic targets for heart failure using bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs111248619 in KCNQ3 was identified in the meta-analysis, yielding a genome-wide significant finding with a p-value of 2.71 x 10^-8.
title: A Novel Type 2 Diabetes Locus in sub-Saharan Africans, ZRANB3, is Implicated in Beta Cell Proliferation

finding: The SNP rs7982 in CLU was associated with reduced AD risk, identifying it as beneficial for longevity free from Alzheimer's disease, confirming its previously established role.
title: Exome-wide age-of-onset analysis reveals exonic variants in ERN1, TACR3 and SPPL2C associated with Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SA1-linked locus rs10109434 was related to academic attainment and cognitive ability, indicating its significance in the genetic underpinnings of these traits.
title: Genomic Structural Equation Modeling Reveals Latent Phenotypes in the Human Cortex with Distinct Genetic Architecture

finding: The SNP rs6651252 was identified as being associated with Crohn's disease. Specifically, it was found to impact MYC gene expression in human colonic epithelial cells. This association highlights a potential mechanism through which genetic variants may influence the development or progression of Crohn's disease, revealing insights into the transcriptional regulation in the context of intestinal health and disease.
title: Single-cell sequencing of developing human gut reveals transcriptional links to childhood Crohn’s disease

finding: For rs10956415, the research identified it as having a moderate effect on cell growth. The finding included converting the alternative allele (A) to the reference allele (C) in MCF7 cells, and this led to a 43.2% average increase in MYC expression compared to unedited cells, correlating with observed cell growth phenotypes.
title: High throughput PRIME editing screens identify functional DNA variants in the human genome

finding: The CLU risk allele (rs9331896) was associated with higher brain levels of APOE_TBS, APOE_TX, and total tau_TBS, suggesting it plays a role in AD-related biochemical dynamics.
title: Genome-wide association study of brain biochemical phenotypes reveals distinct genetic architecture of Alzheimer’s Disease related proteins

finding: The PTK2B risk allele (rs73223431) exhibited associations with increased p-Tau_TX and p-Tau_FA, indicating its role in tau pathology.
title: Genome-wide association study of brain biochemical phenotypes reveals distinct genetic architecture of Alzheimer’s Disease related proteins

finding: The SNP rs10110458 was identified as a significant marker related to elevated expression of splicing factors in neuroblastoma, which was associated with poor clinical outcomes. This finding linked the SNP to mechanisms involving aberrant splicing and RNA-fusions, emphasizing its relevance in the context of cancer progression and potential therapeutic strategies targeting the spliceosome.
title: Alternative splicing in neuroblastoma generates RNA-fusion transcripts and is associated with vulnerability to spliceosome inhibitors

finding: The study found that mice lacking a Myc enhancer that includes the human SNP rs6983267 exhibited resistance to intestinal tumors. This indicates that rs6983267 plays a significant role in the development of intestinal tumors, likely through its association with the regulation of the Myc oncogene.
title: Oncogenic Notch promotes long-range regulatory interactions within hyperconnected 3D cliques

finding: The variant rs28834970 was identified near the CLU and PTK2B genes and was predicted as an outlier in monocytes. It was shown to have decreased regulatory activity associated with the alternative C allele, affecting the expression of PTK2B in macrophages.
title: Regression convolutional neural network models implicate peripheral immune regulatory variants in the predisposition to Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The germline SNP rs4295627 was associated with a 1.3-fold increased risk of glioma development. This SNP was located adjacent to a recurrent somatic structural variation at the lncRNA CCDC26 locus, which was found in 13% of Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG) patients. This highlighted the potential clinical relevance of this SNP in the context of pediatric brain cancer.
title: Recurrent structural variations of lncRNA gene CCDC26 in diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma

finding: Finding rs1947178 indicated it is located downstream of TOX and is associated with increased chromatin accessibility and gene expression related to T1D. The expression analysis showed pronounced accessibility in fruit bat cells, which correlated with upregulation of TOX, underscoring its importance in diabetes.
title: Integrative single-cell characterization of frugivory adaptations in the bat kidney and pancreas

finding: The SNP rs6983267 was studied in the context of intestinal tumors, where it was found that mice lacking a Myc enhancer which included this SNP demonstrated resistance to intestinal tumors. This highlighted the potential link between the SNP and tumorigenesis in the intestinal epithelium, suggesting a significant impact on the molecular pathways affected by Apc mutations.
title: Mutational inactivation of Apc in the intestinal epithelia compromises cellular organisation

finding: The SNP rs4921913, located near the NAT2 gene, was associated with the metabolite AAMU, which is derived from coffee. This association remained significant even after adjustments for coffee intake, indicating the robustness of the finding. The p-values indicated strong significance in both IBD patients and controls, with p-values of 2.2e-16 and 2.0e-09 respectively.
title: The faecal metabolome and its determinants in inflammatory bowel disease

finding: SNP rs35246381 was found to be in linkage disequilibrium with rs4921913 and was associated with the ratio between the metabolites 1,3-dimethylurate and AAMU. The relevance of this association was supported by high r^2 values (r^2 > 0.8), showcasing its connection to coffee metabolism.
title: The faecal metabolome and its determinants in inflammatory bowel disease

finding: The variant rs35241117 displayed the highest frequency globally in Arabia and was associated with multiple traits, including glomerular filtration rate and hypertension. The specific dynamics of its increase in frequency were addressed in the context of selection, but detailed findings regarding its historical trajectory were not included in the provided text.
title: The Genomic History of the Middle East

finding: The variant rs1208, which refers to NAT2*12, was noted for its high allele frequencies (near 100%) in various provinces of China and among East Asians. This finding suggested that genetic testing for this variant may not be necessary before administering isoniazid for tuberculosis treatment in Chinese populations, contrasting with recommendations for other populations where the frequencies were lower.
title: NyuWa Genome Resource: Deep Whole Genome Sequencing Based Chinese Population Variation Profile and Reference Panel

finding: This SNP was observed to influence RPL8 in multiple tissues, showcasing an association with ribosomal pathways that may relate to T2D susceptibility.
title: Understanding functional consequences of type 2 diabetes risk loci using the universal data integration and visualization R package CONQUER

finding: The SNP rs10110444 was linked with a study that discussed the molecular mechanisms regulating organ-specific metastases in epithelial ovarian carcinoma. This finding indicated that variations at this locus might play a role in the development and progression of epithelial ovarian cancer.
title: Centrosome amplification favours survival and impairs ovarian cancer progression

finding: The SNP rs10110414 contributed to the characterization of immune responses in cHL by indicating a relationship with the T-cell dysfunction observed in proximity to HRS cells, particularly highlighting its differential impacts in EBV-negative cases.
title: Epstein-Barr Virus Orchestrates Spatial Reorganization and Immunomodulation within the Classic Hodgkin Lymphoma Tumor Microenvironment

finding: The CLU gene rs11136000 variant showed a significant association with mild cognitive impairment in T2D patients, indicating its potential role in cognitive decline related to diabetes.
title: Analysis of key genes and pathways associated with the pathogenesis of Type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The RUNX1T1 gene rs34269950 was found to be associated with obesity and metabolic syndrome, which are both significant risk factors for type 2 diabetes.
title: Analysis of key genes and pathways associated with the pathogenesis of Type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The SNP rs16901979 was replicated as a positive original finding, being associated with T2E (tumor phenotype) with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.50 and a p-value of 3.90 x 10^-2.
title: Germline determinants of the prostate tumor genome

finding: The SNP rs76748266 replicated its association with gain of NCOA2 in pancreatic cancer, showing a high odds ratio (OR = 6.47) and BH FDR (1.56 x 10^-2).
title: Germline determinants of the prostate tumor genome

finding: The SNP rs11777976 was identified as having a significant change in effect size across different populations in relation to the BMI phenotype. It exhibited a weak positive association with BMI in White and Black ancestry groups, while showing a strong negative effect size of -0.07 in the Chinese population. This SNP is located in the intron of the MSRA gene, previously linked to adiposity and BMI in European populations. Additionally, the minor allele frequency for this SNP was reported to be very high in Europeans (approximately 0.5) but notably low in Asians (0.04), highlighting the ancestral differences in its effect on fat distribution and metabolic disturbance.
title: Multi-ancestry polygenic risk scores using phylogenetic regularization

finding: The SNP rs6983267 was reported as an original finding in the context of MYC regulation. Specifically, it was associated with enhancing susceptibility to intestinal tumors. In the study, mice that lacked a MYC enhancer including this SNP were observed to be resistant to such tumors, illustrating the significance of this genetic variant in tumor development.
title: Controlling gene activation by enhancers through a drug-inducible topological insulator

finding: The SNP rs201082887 was associated with alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels in serum, underscoring its role in liver health and enzyme function in African ancestry populations.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: The variant demonstrated ATU impacts on the ANK1 gene, which relate to differential transcript contributions in hematological contexts.
title: Variant-to-function dissection of rare non-coding GWAS loci with high impact on blood traits

finding: In the context of cannabis use disorder (CUD), SNP rs56372821 exhibited strong evidence of increasing risk, with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.47 and a statistically significant p-value of 0.001 when using a one-SNP instrument. The findings also indicated that this SNP remained associated with CUD as part of a 22-SNP instrument, yielding an OR of 1.13 (p = 0.004), suggesting the SNP was a positive and original finding in this study.
title: Investigating causal pathways between liability to ADHD and substance use, and liability to substance use and ADHD risk, using Mendelian randomization

finding: The rs4129585 SNP, associated with the TSNARE1 gene, was also subjected to deletion during the CRISPR Del/Rei experiments. Deletions concerning this SNP were achieved with efficiencies ranging from approximately 50% to 100% within the bulk transfected iPSCs.
title: CRISPR Del/Rei: A simple, flexible and efficient pipeline for scarless genome editing

finding: The effect size of the rs1293298 SNP (related to the CTSB locus) was noted to show an opposite trend compared to the general population for PD. This SNP was recently identified as a potential genetic modifier for GBA-associated PD, indicating its relevance in the context of LRRK2-related disease mechanisms.
title: Penetrance of Parkinson’s disease in LRRK2 p.G2019S carriers is modified by a polygenic risk score

finding: In the study conducted by Matthews et al. (2019), the SNP rs6651252, which is associated with Crohn's disease, was found to impact MYC gene expression in human colonic epithelial cells. This finding suggested a link between this specific SNP and alterations in metabolic and cellular functions related to the MYC proto-oncogene, which is crucial in cancer biology and metabolic regulation.
title: Premature Aging and Reduced Cancer Incidence Associated with Body-Wide Loss of Myc

finding: The SNP rs10090317 was associated with the transcriptome signatures of canine mammary gland tumors and provided insights into its comparison with human breast cancers. The findings revealed that both species exhibit transcriptomic similarities, which suggested that canine mammary tumors could serve as an effective model for studying mammary cancer progression across species.
title: Molecular Parallelisms and Divergences Between Human and Canine Cancers Would a dog be an appropriate experimental model for human cancers?

finding: The SNP rs10090286 was associated with the expression patterns of Lamin A/C in the context of EBV infection, specifically impacting the latency program of the virus. The study indicated that variations in this SNP may correlate with distinct structural patterns of Lamin A/C expression observed in Hodgkin and Reed-Sternberg cells, which are relevant in understanding the malignancies linked to EBV.
title: The Nuclear Lamina Binds the EBV Genome During Latency and Regulates Viral Gene Expression

finding: The SNP rs6983267 at 8q24.21 has been associated with prostate cancer (CaP), originally identified in European populations. In this study, it displayed similar allele frequencies across African populations, with the risk-increasing G allele found more frequently in cases (98.2%) than controls (97.9%). This suggested that while rs6983267 contributed to differences in CaP risk at a continental level, it had minimal effect on risk differentiation within sub-Saharan Africa.
title: A custom genotyping array reveals population-level heterogeneity for the genetic risks of prostate cancer and other cancers in Africa

finding: The SNP rs2294008, located at 8q24.3, was found to have significant allele frequency differences across African populations. It was associated with bladder and gastric cancer, with frequencies of the risk-increasing allele reported as 28.7% in Senegal, 35.7% in Ghana, 28.8% in Nigeria, and 54.8% in South Africa, with p-values < 0.0001 indicating strong significance in comparisons involving South Africa.
title: A custom genotyping array reveals population-level heterogeneity for the genetic risks of prostate cancer and other cancers in Africa

finding: Linked with luminal-like risk from the previous GWAS studies.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: This SNP displayed indications of involvement in HR-negative disease contexts.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: The variant rs12056334 was linked to fasting insulin (FI) in African American individuals, representing a novel association for this group. This variant is located near the LOC100128993 gene, an uncharacterized RNA gene, suggesting a potentially new area of study in insulin signaling.
title: The Trans-Ancestral Genomic Architecture of Glycaemic Traits

finding: The SNP rs2732317 was associated with effects on gene expression and was indicated to have a regulatory effect affecting transcription factor binding sites for GABPA, ETS1, ELF1, and ELK1 in the FUT10 promoter region. This finding was supported by analysis from the ENCODE project.
title: RSAT Var-tools: an accessible and flexible framework to predict the impact of regulatory variants on transcription factor binding

finding: In conjunction with rs2732317, the minor alleles of SNP rs2732318 were also part of the identified heterozygous haplotype affecting the binding of multiple transcription factors including EHF/ELF2 and others. This indicates a potential regulatory impact on gene expression.
title: RSAT Var-tools: an accessible and flexible framework to predict the impact of regulatory variants on transcription factor binding

finding: The SNP CCAT2 rs6983267 was associated with colorectal cancer (CRC), confirming previous findings from independent populations. Carriers of the T-allele had about 30% lower risk of CRC compared to GG homozygotes, and an interaction with red and processed meat intake was noted.
title: Intake of red and processed meat, use of non-steroid anti inflammatory drugs, genetic variants and risk of colorectal cancer; a prospective study of the Danish “Diet, Cancer and Health” cohort

finding: The SNP rs6983267 was mentioned in the context of the MYC region, which has been previously fine-mapped and highlights its role in PrCa risk.
title: H3k27ac-HiChIP in prostate cell lines identifies risk genes for prostate cancer susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs73348588 was highlighted as the lead SNP within an intron of ADCY8 that associated with breast cancer (OR = 1.13; P = 8.2e-7). It was part of a genomic region where a 144Kb downstream deletion showed a strong association with breast cancer, indicating a potential link between CNVs and common genetic variants in breast cancer susceptibility.
title: Rare copy number variants (CNVs) and breast cancer risk

finding: The CLU gene rs11136000 variant was associated with mild cognitive impairment in type 2 diabetic patients. Although this primarily concerns cognitive function, it emphasizes genetic contributions in metabolic disorders linking to GDM.
title: Identification of differentially expressed genes and signaling pathways in gestational diabetes mellitus by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The rs7824905 variant in the PLCG2 gene, identified as a rare missense variant (P522R), was found to decrease the risk of late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD). This protective effect was associated with a notable preservation of synaptic integrity and reduced microglial engulfment of synapses, independent of amyloid burden. This finding emphasized the role of PLCG2 in mediating synaptic loss in Alzheimer's pathology.
title: Uncoupling of synaptic loss from amyloid burden by an Alzheimer’s disease protective variant of PLCγ2

finding: The SNP rs6983267 was identified as a significant cancer risk variant associated with long-range interactions with the MYC gene in colorectal cancer. This finding demonstrates its relevance in the context of cancer biology, particularly in understanding the genetic factors that contribute to colorectal cancer susceptibility.
title: Using three-dimensional regulatory chromatin interactions from adult and fetal cortex to interpret genetic results for psychiatric disorders and cognitive traits

finding: The study identified the rs1390938 polymorphism (Thr136Ile) as unique to humans, with all other vertebrate species retaining asparagine at the 136th residue in the VMAT1 gene. The introduction of this human-specific mutation into mice via CRISPR/Cas9 revealed reduced anxiety-related traits, supporting findings from human studies. Additionally, neurophysiological assessments showed altered oscillatory activity in the amygdala, linking the mutation to significant behavioral and molecular changes associated with emotion and cognition.
title: Humanized substitutions of Vmat1 in mice induce changes in amygdala-dependent behaviors associated with the evolution of anxiety in humans

finding: The SNP rs7010143 was linked to paracrine interactions between adipocytes and tumor cells, playing a significant role in recruiting and modifying macrophages within the mammary tumor microenvironment. This study highlighted the influence of obesity and inflammation in breast adipose tissue, suggesting that genetic variations such as rs7010143 could affect tumor behavior and metabolism, particularly in the context of breast cancer.
title: In vivo optical metabolic imaging of long-chain fatty acid uptake in orthotopic models of triple negative breast cancer

finding: In the experiment conducted at the Mayo Clinic, SNP rs55705857 was introduced into a human astrocyte cell line (AA7) through genome editing. The editing involved replacing a fragment of DNA on chromosome 8 with a designed template, which also included a hygromycin resistance gene for selection. Upon analysis using Sanger sequencing, this SNP was confirmed in two of the edited clones, indicating a successful edit and specific identification of the alteration in the target allele.
title: Clonally selected lines after CRISPR/Cas editing are not isogenic

finding: This SNP was recognized as a lead SNP for one of the novel loci associated with cIMT, contributing to a better understanding of atherosclerosis mechanisms.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: This SNP was found to be in high linkage disequilibrium with the previously reported lead SNP rs2912063, confirming its relevance in the context of cIMT.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: Found to be consistent with previously identified SNPs in the analyses for both men and the primary sex-combined study, reaffirming its genetic association.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: The rs1532278 SNP, linked to myopia and residing in an intron of CLU, was accessible across multiple retinal cell types but its functional impact was specifically observed in Müller glia, where it was predicted to regulate CLU expression.
title: Single-cell multiome of the human retina and deep learning nominate causal variants in complex eye diseases

finding: The study found that the SNP rs112892337 was associated with the phenotype "Comparative height size at age 10" (UK Biobank Field ID: 1697) with a MAF of 0.4% and a p value of 3.0E-15, located in the gene ZFAT.
title: Efficient mixed model approach for large-scale genome-wide association studies of ordinal categorical phenotypes

finding: The interaction involving rs987525 and the methylation levels in the enhancer region was significant in both the CL/P and control datasets. However, the significance disappeared when the number of methylation strata increased, indicating potential issues with false positives.
title: Gene-methylation interactions: Discovering region-wise DNA methylation levels that modify SNP-associated disease risk

finding: The variant rs4129585 was identified as a significant regulatory element associated with schizophrenia risk. It was shown to drive reporter gene expression in zebrafish and was found to differentially regulate the expression of 109 genes significantly and 259 genes at a less stringent threshold during the differentiation of iPSCs into neural precursors. Specifically, it suggested potential regulatory functions on the <italic>ADGRB1</italic> gene, a known regulator of synaptogenesis, while no significant effects were observed on <italic>TSNARE1</italic> transcripts.
title: A Functional Schizophrenia-associated genetic variant near the TSNARE1 and ADGRB1 genes

finding: Associated with similar features as rs4976977, providing consistent insights into genetic contributions to cognitive function.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: The variant rs2620666 was found to be in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with SNPs rs750472 and rs13251458, which were associated with several cognitive traits. It was determined to overlap a RAMPAGE-verified unannotated transcription start site (TSS) of the PPP1R16A gene, despite being only 1,694 bp upstream of a GENCODE-annotated TSS of this gene. The novel TSS was notably supported by PacBio reads and exhibited high RAMPAGE signal in neural cells, brain tissues, and blood cells. Furthermore, it was identified as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for several genes, including PPP1R16A, implying a potential influence of this variant on gene expression.
title: A catalog of transcription start sites across 115 human tissue and cell types

finding: The SNP rs6983267 was associated with the Myc enhancer, and research showed that mice lacking this enhancer were resistant to intestinal tumors. This finding indicated that the enhancer containing rs6983267 plays a significant role in tumorigenesis, particularly in the context of intestinal cancer.
title: Uncovering Hidden Enhancers Through Unbiased In Vivo Testing

finding: The SNP rs7017386 was identified as a colorectal cancer risk variant. It was found to modulate the expression of two oncogenic long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) through an ATF1-mediated long-range chromatin loop. This finding emphasized the importance of chromatin structures in the regulation of gene expression relevant to cancer pathways.
title: Computational Enhanced Hi-C data reveals the function of structural geometry in genomic regulation

finding: At the PLAG1-CHCHD7 locus for birth weight, the PIP for rs72656010 improved from 0.80 to 0.97 when incorporating the cV2F score. This variant was implicated by ABC, cCRE, Enformer, and Zoonomia features. The variant was linked to the PLAG1 and CHCHD7 genes, with PLAG1 being previously implicated in growth-related traits through animal studies.
title: A consensus variant-to-function score to functionally prioritize variants for disease

finding: At the GATA4/NEIL2 locus for Apolipoprotein A, the PIP for rs17810889 improved from 0.78 to 0.98 with the Liver-cV2F score, compared to 0.81 with the primary cV2F score. This variant was implicated by Liver-ABC, Liver-ChromBPNet, and Liver-Enformer features, and strongly linked to the NEIL2 gene, which encodes DNA glycosylase enzymes and has been implicated in mutagenesis.
title: A consensus variant-to-function score to functionally prioritize variants for disease

finding: The SNP rs1478898 was identified as an eQTL for the FAM66A gene, which was disrupted by the inversion at the distal breakpoint. This disruption was part of a larger investigation into genetic factors influencing obesity-related traits.
title: Polymorphic inversions underlie the shared genetic susceptibility to prevalent common diseases

finding: SNP rs140730217 was associated with the FAM66D gene, where the inversion split its gene body. This separation likely impacted the regulatory relationship between the promoter and the eQTL SNP, making it a strong candidate for involvement in obesity.
title: Polymorphic inversions underlie the shared genetic susceptibility to prevalent common diseases

finding: This SNP, located on EPHX2, was recorded as a novel GWS locus for smoking initiation in this study, aligning with earlier findings of its link to the same trait.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The variant rs11557049 was described as the locus lead variant for the PDE7A gene, which had not been previously reported in association with kidney function. This SNP was part of a 99% credible set consisting of a single protein-altering variant, underscoring its potential role in kidney function research.
title: Discovery and prioritization of variants and genes for kidney function in >1.2 million individuals

finding: This SNP was found in the exon region of CYP11B2, which is involved in the conversion of corticosterone to aldosterone. It was identified that African American (AA) men with prostate cancer (PrCa) exhibited a significantly higher frequency of the SNP, suggesting a potential impact on CYP11B2 function and an enhanced ability to convert corticosterone to aldosterone.
title: Racial differences in androgen metabolism and receptor signaling in prostate cancer

finding: Similar to rs5313, this SNP is located in the exon region of CYP11B2 and was also found in higher frequencies among AA men with PrCa. This indicates that it may potentially influence the function of CYP11B2, which plays a crucial role in the biosynthesis of aldosterone from corticosterone in AA men with prostate cancer.
title: Racial differences in androgen metabolism and receptor signaling in prostate cancer

finding: This indel variant was significantly associated with chromatin accessibility and expression of the <italic>SLC26A7</italic> gene in progenitors. It was co-localized with an index SNP linked to inter-individual differences in brain structure.
title: Inferring cell-type-specific causal gene regulatory networks during human neurogenesis

finding: The rs56094005 variant in the DOK2 gene was found to be associated with lymphocyte count, along with other immune cell types such as monocytes, neutrophils, and platelets, in a substantial trans-ethnic analysis involving 750,000 individuals including those from the UK Biobank. This finding marked it as a positive original association in the current study.
title: An allelic series rare variant association test for candidate gene discovery

finding: rs72725879 was significant in both the African American and Japanese American cohorts. In the African American cohort, it was part of a cluster with an average PIP of 0.994, while in the Japanese American cohort, it exhibited a strong PIP of 0.815, indicating its relevance in prostate cancer risk across these diverse populations.
title: Multi-ethnic transcriptome-wide association study of prostate cancer

finding: rs1456315 was the most significantly associated SNP identified in the Japanese American GWAS, with a P-value of 1.40 × 10^-13. It was also linked with rs72725879 in the Japanese American cohort, suggesting a shared significance in influencing prostate cancer risk.
title: Multi-ethnic transcriptome-wide association study of prostate cancer

finding: rs76595456 was highlighted as the most significantly associated SNP overall, specifically is linked to individuals of recent African ancestries, and showed an individual PIP of 0.942, further confirming its significance as a population-specific risk factor for prostate cancer.
title: Multi-ethnic transcriptome-wide association study of prostate cancer

finding: The SNP rs17321515 was associated with coronary heart disease and NAFLD in specific populations, underscoring its role in cardiovascular and liver-related health concerns.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI

finding: SNP rs114629793 had a P-value of 8.65 × 10^-8 and was located in the intron of PSD3, a gene previously implicated in schizophrenia and brain reward circuitry dysfunction, suggesting its role in cocaine use disorder.
title: Retrospective Association Analysis of Longitudinal Binary Traits Identifies Important Loci and Pathways in Cocaine Use

finding: The variant rs2046338 was prioritized in a multiple sclerosis GWAS region and was linked to the regulation of the immune-related gene IL7. It was found to be in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with the sentinel GWAS variant (European R2 = 0.99, African R2 = 0.95). Further analysis indicated that the C allele of this variant increased chromatin accessibility in the region, observed in 44 out of 48 heterozygous samples. The variant was associated with the creation of a binding motif for OCT family transcription factors, suggesting its significance in IL7 transcriptional regulation.
title: Transcriptomics and chromatin accessibility in multiple African population samples

finding: The variant rs582283 was found to disrupt the RBP binding site of YBX3 in the gene MS4A3, leading to skipping of exon 7, which was implicated in Alzheimer’s disease. This suggested a mechanism of action related to the splicing alteration caused by the variant, which was statistically significant in the context of the disease.
title: A Deep Dive into Statistical Modeling of RNA Splicing QTLs Reveals New Variants that Explain Neurodegenerative Disease

finding: The rs6410 variant was associated with skeletal aging and was experimentally verified to promote retention of intron 3 of CYP11B1. This finding highlighted the importance of considering splicing variations in understanding the genetic factors associated with disease.
title: A Deep Dive into Statistical Modeling of RNA Splicing QTLs Reveals New Variants that Explain Neurodegenerative Disease

finding: The SNP rs28601761 in lincRNA RP11-136O12.2 was pleiotropic for cardiovascular disease, HbA1c, and blood triglyceride levels, indicating its relevance in various metabolic and cardiovascular conditions.
title: Causal inference for multiple risk factors and diseases from genomics data

finding: The rs6983267 variant was associated with prostate cancer through its influence on POU5F1B expression, facilitated by chromatin interactions with AR binding sites.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The SNP rs10110456 was identified in the context of glioma research. It was associated with glioma migration and infiltration properties, which suggested its potential role as a target for personalized radiation medicine in cancer treatment.
